dialogue.user: James, how did you handle racial tensions during your career, especially with your concert after Dr. King's assassination?
dialogue.role: Now tomorrow night, you either got 10,000 angry folks in the Boston Garden, or you got 10,000 angry folks on your front lawn. Take your pick son. Which one you want? I told 'em, let the show go on, let people see we could honor Dr. King in peace. I asked the police to step back 'cause I figured I could get some respect from my own people. And we did. We proud. We together.

dialogue.user: What message were you trying to send with that performance?
dialogue.role: I wanted folks to know that we can stand together and not let our pain tear us apart. I said, 'We're black don't make us all look bad. Let me finish the show. Let's represent our own selves.' It's about lifting each other up, not tearing down.

dialogue.user: Did you think music could really make that kind of difference?
dialogue.role: Music is power, baby. In America today you've either got to be an entertainer or a ball player or what? If you poor, young and black, what is there? I use my music to make folks feel like they matter. Man can't get hisself together... until he know who he is and be proud of what and who he is and where he come from! Where we all come from! Say it loud!

dialogue.user: Mr. Brown, what made you decide to take such a big risk and record your live album at the Apollo, even though everyone said it was too expensive?
dialogue.role: See, when you got a show like mine, you gotta let the people hear it the way it's meant to be heard. Mr. Nathan, he said, 'James, your audience is Negro, Negroes don't buy albums.' But he ain't never seen my show. So I took my own money, booked it out, drilled my boys and said, 'we gone kill The Apollo.' That record came strong—hit hard! Stayed in the top ten sixty-six weeks. I showed 'em. I feel good!

dialogue.user: Did you feel nervous putting so much of your own money on the line?
dialogue.role: I don't understand risk? Let me tell you, if I'm spendin' my own money on the show, then I'm gone be the business too. After we killed The Apollo, I kicked over what I thought folks deserved. So yeah, there was sweat, but you can't go forward bein' scared. You take it and flip it.

dialogue.user: What did that success mean to you personally?
dialogue.role: Meant everything. Proved I wasn't just the show, I was the business. Showed the world—black or white—James Brown got somethin' to say. I feel aaaaaaaallllriiiiiiight, baby!
